awd_titl_txt: RIDIR: Collaborative Research: DAPPR: Diffusion Analytics for Public Policy Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Stability in social, technical, and financial systems, as well as the capacity of organizations to work across borders, requires consistency in public policy across jurisdictions. However, progress depends upon innovative policy solutions to society's problems. The transmission of laws and regulations across political boundaries averts a conflict between the incentives for innovation and consistency.  The current project will offer a database that allows the tracking of the spread of policies through the US states. The database will be disseminated through project webpages. The web interface will also include advanced analytics that illuminate the pathways through which policies spread. Users will be able to download the data and software for their own custom analysis of policy transmission in the US states. 

Policy diffusion has been a topic of focus across the social sciences for several decades, but due to limitations of data and computational technology, researchers have not taken a comprehensive look at patterns of diffusion across many different policies. The investigators propose to combine cutting-edge methods of text and network analysis to understand how policies, as represented in digitized text, spread through networks connecting the American states. The investigators will develop both data and computational methods that address the most pressing limitations to the study of policy diffusion networks. The project will result in two key contributions: (1) a comprehensive source of data with which to track the movement of policies from one state government to another, across three governing branches, and (2) a user-friendly, open source software package for understanding and visualizing diffusion networks from digitized records of policies. These resources will help researchers, public officials, advocacy groups, and other relevant stakeholders understand how to balance the competing goals of innovation and consistency in public policy.

por.por_cntn:
Policymaking plays an important role in addressing new societal challenges. As societies and communities repeatedly face similar political circumstances and uncertainty, the making and deployment of policies often involve a learning or diffusion process across political boundaries, in which political actors look to each other when making policy choices. Policy diffusion research has been a focal topic across the social sciences for several decades, but limitations of data and computational techniques have hindered the progress necessary to advance the policymaking process. This multi-institutional, interdisciplinary research makes several contributions in developing research infrastructure to overcome the challenge.

First, this project produced a publicly-available, longitudinal database that extensively tracks the movement of policies from one state government to another, across three governing branches covering the judiciary, legislature, and regulatory agencies in the US. This new database represents the first comprehensive look at the diffusion of public policies, enabling further studies of policy innovation within and across American states.

Second, to facilitate the use of the collected data, we developed analytical tools and training materials available to the public. We created a user-friendly, open-source software toolkit for understanding and visualizing policy diffusion processes. The tool combines visual analytics, with text and network analyses to help understand how policies, as represented in digitized text, spread across time and space. With interactive system design, it enables expert and non-expert users to inspect the influence across states along the diffusion trajectory of a particular policy.

Third, our research outcomes have been disseminated to a broader set of audiences through presentations at conferences and seminars across different fields. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, a planned conference to be held during the 2020 Midwest Political Science Association's annual meeting, was canceled.  We hence dedicated our efforts to creating online digital training materials, which can be distributed more widely than an in-person conference.

Finally, this project has led to significant educational impacts through such a cross-disciplinary and cross-institutional collaboration. It has involved graduate and undergraduate students in Political Science and Computing and Information Sciences, from all seven universities. The collaboration provides rich opportunities for students to deepen their understanding of the research from different disciplinary angles and to learn how to properly communicate the scientific work with the research team.

This project offers two broader impacts. First, the data and techniques enable researchers, public officials, advocacy groups, and other relevant stakeholders to discover and communicate the insights from policymaking history, including how to balance the competing goals of innovation and consistency in public policy. Second, the data can be used to illuminate topics and a set of regional hubs of policy innovation in the American states, which helps stakeholders to build strategies and collaboration across borders.
